ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: Jay Nuremburg
Jason Nerenberg
jason
Jason Nerenberg
Jason Nerenberg
Jay Nerenberg
Phillip Marshall
Jason Nerenberg
Jason
Jay
Jason Nerenberg

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Philip's instruction was incredible, especially in the field. I really appreciated his knowledge, thoroughness and incredible patience. He really went the extra mile for us.Prof. Camp was also very helpful at every turn and gave good lectures.The only thing I could criticize at all about this course is that we ignored herbaceous species, but this was by design.

7a. Philip Marshall knows everything anyone could possibly know about the history of individual tree species. He is an unbelievable wealth of knowledge.7b. Jason always had time to answer questions and even led a review session before the test without anyone having to ask him. He was attentive and helpful in each class and on field trips.8/10. Even students who are not MF should take this course because it provides a foundational knowledge of and familiarity with tree taxonomy and identification.9. The field trips, especially Sleeping Giant and Yale-Myers were amazing. The bog was my favorite part of any class that I have taken since undergrad.However, I would have the list of species to be seen at each field trip available at least a week ahead of time so that students can read up on them before going into the field. If we get the species list the day of, it was more difficult for some students to keep up when going from tree to tree.
response to 6- the amount of material we had to get through made lectures somewhat encyclopedic, so we didn't get to focus on individual families as much as they deserve

Because the course was taught by two instructors, Ann and Phil, the pace and kind of instruction really varied depending on who was lecturing. They both have unique teaching styles which can be good depending on your learning style.

1. I found the organization of both texts confusing, as neither did a good job grouping according to families and orders clearly. But in the end I was glad I had purchased both.3. The midterm was a lot of fun, but it would have been great to have discussed it in class afterwards in order to learn what Phil had been looking for in each question.7a. Both professors demonstrated a tremendous depth of knowledge and worked amiably together. I wanted to give an excellent rating, but two things held me back - 1) Both instructors did too much reading directly from their Powerpoints when presenting to the class. 2) At times the instructors competed too much with each other - especially on field excursions. Phil's command of natural history knowledge was boundless and added a tremendous amount to the class. Ann's ability to incorporate West Coast species was enlightening.7c. It wasn't that Jay did a poor job as TA, it was that he contributed so little that at times it didn't feel as if we had a TA.9. The field trips MADE this class. I learned so much more rapidly in the field and my retention was 10-fold over the class lectures. The instructors did a fantastic time making sure we got outside as much as possible and it made a huge difference (even if it meant just walking around Farnham Memorial Gardens or Greeley Gardens).
Phillip Marshall is an invaluable asset to FES as an instructor. His knowledge made the class what it was - a very valuable course to anyone with an interest in trees.

The course requires a lot of individual work in the form of memorization and practice but with that, one comes away with a terrific understanding of tree identification skills. The main instructor is more than incredibly knowledgeable, and both teachers seem to be working very hard to modify parts of this relatively new course to make it even better. The course is great, but would benefit from some relatively minor changes, and may a few larger ones. Minor changes: as much practice time/ field work as possible, and maybe some structured group activities during that field time; smaller practicum-type assignments along the way (maybe ID quizzes?) at each field trip; have the 3-hour lecture chunk include a 30 minute ID session of species relevant to the lecture that are near-by (a short walking tour of the day's trees). Maybe larger changes: It would be good to more clearly decide/ define the purpose of the course. Is it about learning to ID trees or to understand their place in an overall system/ natural history context? I know it's currently both, but it would help students to learn "both sides" better if these goals were integrated more. How can you integrate the natural history and the ID better so each accentuates our understanding of both? Are there discussion activities that might engage students in the natural history portion more during lectures?

This class was terrific.Due to the weather constrictions, it is a must that we do the field trips prior to the bulk of classification lectures. Ideally they would be done beforehand, but it's not possible. I think this is understood, and it's appreciated by students that we get outside w/ the leaves still on!The field trips were AMAZING. I learned so much. One suggestion to Philip Marshall as an instructor would be to do more "quizzing" of students while we are in the field. We ask him so many questions which he answers thoroughly and generously. I wouldn't want him to change that but I think there could be some benefit for him to turning some of the questions back on to us.When we are in the field, it is very easy to get sucked into focusing on tree ID entirely, but it would also be helpful to work in some of the more conceptual classification and evolutionary discussions while we are out and about.
Tree ID field trips! Amazing!
Instructors.

The field trips were very helpful in learning to identify the trees, and in learning interesting connections between the history, site preferences, and other interesting aspects of trees in New England.
Definitely the field trips.
Field trips were adequate and informative, I would recommend more field time to emphasize classroom material.
The field trips were the best part. That was where we got firsthand experience at identifying woody species. We had the opportunity to visit a diverse array of habitats.
field trips by far, and our instructor's amazing off the cuff knowledge of trees
The field trips and the very hands-on learning about new england tree ID. I particularly appreciated when we talked about how species or genus fit into the ecology of an area.

1. The instructors - the depth of their knowledge, personalities, and approach.2. The amount of field time and what we learned during that time.3. The quaking bog.4. Field practical - one of the most practical exams I have ever taken.5. The class schedule. Perfect amount of Friday trips and thought that 3 hours once a week was very perfectly suited to the material that had to be covered.
Field trips - really helped to put the class material with its context.
- Philip- learning to ID trees
Field trips. I would do even more of them. Phillip and Ann are incredible resources.

Really informative field moments: quaking bog and atlantic white cedar - a visceral habitat heuristic. 4 cupressaceae in the meadow in east rock park, next to one another.Mostly: getting outside, seeing trees, connecting land use history to incidence of individuals and species. the field trips are the best part - hands down.
Becoming more familiar with the trees in Southern New England.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: It should be a two semester course!
It was difficult to absorb all of the material from the lectures.

Maybe reorganize the slides so that each class begins with a picture of the phylogenetic tree with the portion to be discussed that day highlighted (i.e. the rosid clade, fabid clade, malvid clade, etc.). Then, only do the families and species within that clade. It was more difficult and took longer when studying for the final to have to organize everything to get the big picture.
Classroom was a little too small for the amount of students in the class.
Sometimes people were confused about the expectations for assignments.

the lectures get to be encyclopedic and are long since the class only meets once a week for 3 hours. It may be nice to have the option of switching to two 1.5 hour sessions once the field trips are over.

There was more work in this class than other classes. I think that only one midterm (either the take home or the field practicum would be sufficient). Also, the final paper was so loosely defined that I didn't really understand what the instructors were hoping that we would get out of the assignment except to jump through another hoop.

I would strongly suggest that the instructors distribute a large taxonomic chart on the first day of class. Then, throughout the remainder of the lectures the students could be engaged in populating the chart. It would better establish an understanding of families and orders as we went along, rather than being something that's merely studied for the final exam.A move involved TA would have made an already excellent class even better.Smaller Powerpoint file sizes.

- providing time and guidance in class to learn the trees along the way (more practice, maybe field trip quizzes, etc.)- figuring out how to make the natural history portion seem more relevant and connected to the taxonomy portion
The lectures were a little dry. There was a lot of information that we probably could of read in a book. I would of enjoyed a little less tree taxonomy and a bit more natural history.

Learning 'check in' questions asked of students.Integrating tree ID with taxonomy and classification concepts. in the field time is very heavily weighted toward ID.I felt very unprepared to answer the questions posed in the midterm - iwanted to be able to answer them and in researching the questions i gained a lot of insight into certain things I should have been focusing on in my reading and listening to lectures.I like the "thinking" questions posed in some of the handouts for the field trips, and wished we had focused a bit more on the answers/discussion to them. This would have increased the "applied" practice during the course.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Instructor was willing and available to give help and and the quality of that help was high.

Philip is extremely knowledegable about the subject matter, and is able to communicate the information very well to the students. He also shows a level of patience (when we have to repeatedly ask him to identify a certain species) that I would expect to see in very few teachers. Ann's comments in class and on the field trips were also very helpful, as they generally provided a somewhat different perspective than Philip.
I did not personally contact the professor or the TA, but they were always available via email or in person.
Availability of the TA was limited, the availability of the instructor was fantastic.
They were always willing to help, although I never asked for individual assistance. The TA led a study session in preparation for the final exam.
instructor (Phil)- he was very quick to respond and always very knowledgeable.
good. both Ann and Phil were great, particularly in the field
Didn't ever seek extra help outside of class time.
Whenever I had a question I would email or ask Phillip. He was incredibly responsive and helpful in his replies.
It didn't seem like the TA had much to do, but he was helpful when you needed him and he's knowledgeable. It's good to have several people on the field trips to help with ID.
Jay was gerat.Very knowledgeable TA and good to have out in the field.
Very available, very helpful.
Professor Marshall was always willing to help. He truly wants his students to succeed.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This course was enormously relevant to both my interests and my career plans.
I have a new appreciation of the role of forests in New England, and I feel more confident in my ability to navigate within the context of forests throughout my time at FES and afterwards.

As an MEM candidate, I feel that this course was important because I have a background in taxonomy from undergrad. It is important for me to be able to identify trees, but I may not need it for my eventual career. It was valuable nonetheless.
This course will prepare me for management of species that have cultural natural history associated with them.

I am interested in urban forestry and community forestry, so this course gives me a solid grounding in understanding the site preferences and ecological significances of a wide variety of trees and shrubs, which is essential for anyone doing that kind of work.
It is essential to know the trees of New England if you are doing anything related to ecology

I can't imagine being a Forestry or Forest Science student and not taking this class (unless you already had obtained this knowledge elsewhere). It makes the job you are learning to do tangible and the field time impresses on you where you are and what you are doing.
It's mostly just for personal edification, but it would be really useful for anyone going into actual forestry. And it seems like it should be required of anyone in FES actually -
It doesn't really fit into my degree.

This course "colored in the lines" drawn for me in my stand dynamics class. Learning about the characteristics and tendencies of certain species made me feel much more comfortable with the highly abstract material presented in Stands. These two classes were highly synergistic and I'm so glad that I took them at the same time.Having little background in forestry, I felt this class really increased my fluency with the particular species in southern new england and gave me the tools i need to approach learning specifics about other regions. I feared it might be too specialized toward SNE forests, but it actually feels very transferable in the end.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn about Trees
Because I expected to learn field ID and the way the plant families are related. Both expectations were exceeded.
I like being able to identify things. My undergrad did not have any dendrology courses, so this course essentially completed and served as a capstone for my taxonomic studies.
To become more familiar with the natural history of trees of the New England area.
See above (question 15)
to learn how to identify trees in the field and to know their ecological characteristics
to learn the trees of the area
It seemed fundamental and a can't miss.

I'm very interested in botany and wanted to be able to ID trees. Also I took a course similar to this as an undergrad that focused on herbaceous species rather than trees and it was my favorite class in college.
I took the course purely for pleasure. I didn't want to leave a school of forestry and without learning some basics of forest ecology.
Dendrology basics, wanting to know how to ID trees that I grew up around.
I took this course so I could familiarize myself with the trees we see in southern New England forests.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: yes
Yeah, totally.
Yes.
Yes, Philip Marshall was fantastic. He presented in a knowledgable professional way, I very much enjoyed the course.
Yes, it did. I was able to build upon my prior knowledge of some species while also learning afresh about other species that I had previously never known about.
sure did!
yes
Definitely!!! My semester would have been much less enjoyable and profitable without it.

Mostly. I think it would really benefit from adding some experiences along the way to help students learn the material as we go. Things didn't really "click" enough until the process of studying for the exam.
yes.
Yes - exceeded them.
Yes. It was very challenging, and parts required lots of memorization. However, the course was honestly fun to take, and interesting.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes.
yes
Yes, exactly what I expected.
yes, I very much wanted to learn about trees and important aspects of their natural history and that expectation was met.
Yes
sure did, and more!
yes
You bet.
Yes
yes. though as I said, I would of enjoyed a little bit more natural history.
More.
Yes, I did.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: group work was minimal, but useful.
We studied for the final together, created phylogenetic trees on countless sheets of paper, and memorized them.
Only briefly. Before the final exam a group of us got together and had a study session. It was interesting to see the different ways that people represented and organized the information.
I worked in a group for the final project and we learned a lot from each other. It was a tremendous opportunity!
I was part of a group project in Guilford designing an arbor tour on the town streets and thoroughly enjoyed the group work. I thought we really fed well off our joint brainstorming and ID-sleuthing.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: always write down the latin name 1st before you write anything else.
Ask questions.
Start making your tree identification charts and phylogenetic trees early.
Be prepared to think in a three dimensional way when looking at trees in the field.

If you have little/no experience with tree species in general or New England forests in particular, this course may be extremely challenging for you and will involve a lot of well-organized memorization. If you have some experience and prior knowledge (I had some), you will not find it quite as difficult, but it will still require a substantial amount of memorization.
start a large phylogenetic tree and fill it in as the semester goes on while you learn the different plant orders and families
go on all the field trips and ask lots of questions. study a lot before the exams and you will be able to learn all the information.
If a taxonomic tree isn't passed out, make your own and populate it as you go along. Attend each and every field excursion. Buy the Judd textbook - it helps with exams.

You learn a lot if you put a lot into it. Information is presented once in lecture format, and that's it - you need to work with it on your own. The field trips are very useful but make sure you take the initiative both on the field trips and in your own time to practice IDing species.
do the readings.

Start memorizing everything very early. If you don't have a great memory, like me, then you need to get on top of classifications and identifications of trees as early as possible. There is a lot of material covered in this class, and most of it needs to be retained.
